intro: Machaerina gaudichaudii, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a member of the Asphodelaceae family and is native to New Zealand. It is a perennial shrub that typically grows in coastal and lowland areas, characterized by its sword-shaped leaves and yellow flowers. The plant has fibrous bark that was historically used by Māori for making clothing and baskets. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to the temperate climate of its native habitat. Machaerina gaudichaudii plays an important ecological role in its environment, providing habitat and food for various native species.
